reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend you check back on this game when it's released. If you like exploration-driven adventure games, this one has potential. At the moment it feels like it's a bit low on content, but at the current rate it will likely be quite an interesting game when it's finally released.

You start off as a teenager packing their things and saying goodbye to their family house, about to leave for college. Depending on what you do and what you pack determines where your life takes you (you end up on one of several different maps" for the second round of exploration). Where you explore and what you interact with determines how the rest of your character's life pans out.

It's less than an hour long per playthrough
date: but it's fun going back and trying different things to take your character through a different path in life.\n\nIn the game's current Early Access state (15 July 2015)
recommended: it seems like all of the different life paths are implemented but it's still lacking enough detail to make some of the exploration parts interesting. I enjoyed my first two playthroughs of it
hoursPlayed: but there were some boring bits that I hope will be fixed."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW - September 07, 2015
It's not at all worth a purchase in it's current state, but I write this review to help ensure that it is when it's done.

Feature        Y/N/Rating                SLI        No                Aspect Ratios        16:9, no info on others                Framerate Cap        120-144+                FOV        Yes, 90 Max                Key Rebinding        None                Controller Support/Rebinding        Yes, No                Options        Extensive, but Broken                Performance        Horrible
PC Port Quality
The options are very extensive, shockingly so when I first opened the game, but there are two key problems. 1. None of the options stick properly, not even mouse sensitivity or FOV. If you crouch/run/zoom/throw/climb or view any cutscene, FOV reverts to the extremely low minimum. You're extremely limited in what you can do without going back to the options menu every 3 seconds. The slider should modify the base value, and the different cameras should adjust that and revert to the base when finished, but instead it seems they revert to a set value. 2. The performance is abysmal for the visuals on display, though it's mainly very specific settings and the way the game streams textures. Some settings can completely change the visuals in a really non-intuitive way to little performance impact. Depth of field looks nice in some scenarios, but it seems to just be a near and far blur that doesn't change, rather than focusing on the cursor. If you push up against a wall, it's pure blur. There are dozens of bugs regarding the settings to what I'd say is a pretty unimpressive result fidelity-wise. Tons of pop-in, both seemingly intentional and unintentional. More on that below. Finally, it desperately needs a dedicated full-screen option as it can lose focus behind the taskbar somehow, and lose mouse bounding while using the menus.

Gameplay
I enjoy exploring 3D environments, especially when there are fun physics things to play with. This game is just hinting at that. The grabbing mechanics feel satisfying and are largely fine outside of the FOV reverting issue and that come objects shoot straight into the character and snap back and fourth when grabbed. There are tons of drawers and containers to open, but rarely anything of interest. The basketball outside was a lot of fun to play with, and I'd say the game could benefit massively from more things like it. There are tons of medium/small objects that are static in the environment, and it's a shame not being allowed to mess with them. Also higher texture quality on objects with text, and the ability to rotate objects while zooming (right click) and say holding shift, would be fantastic.

Once you leave the first level with the home, the amount of things to interact and play with jumps straight off a cliff. The house already felt a little bare, but in later levels there's almost nothing at all except a few pebbles by the lake shores. There needs to be puzzles, things to interact with, really anything of interest!

Mouse acceleration is a touch too strong, and while movement in general okay, it could be improved significantly. I feel sprinting speed should be increased, and the player should be allowed to jump and fall off small ledges like the second story in the cabin at the start of the forest area. Snapping to the ladder awkwardly to go up or down, on top of the FOV resetting, was beyond clumsy. Finally, you should be able to sprint while carrying objects, and be able to strafe while sprinting as well. Being locked into only forward movement while running endlessly through the forest level felt really restricting.

Presentation
Assuming various fidelity issues are addressed, the game actually can look pretty nice. However, it's key problem is also it's main gimmick. Filling in color as you progress through the environment. It works okay in the first house environment, where it's triggered by fully exploring the contents of the room. The black and white interiors are unappealing, and while the colored versions are an improvement, they aren't great either. Outside however, in the forest area of the game (the second level")
date: the filled in colored versions are bright and vibrant. Certain scenes are screenshot-worthy. That said
recommended: that's AFTER you fill in the area with color

Early Access Review

Pretentious tripe.

This isn't a real game.

Say what you will about walking simulators" like Dear Esther or the numerous Crysis 1 mods that I helped beta test (Triptych
date: Worry of Newport)  but those were polished pieces of immersive fiction with fantastic graphics
voteText: and good stories.\n\nThis "game" has a good concept where your day to day actions will have consequences in your future. However
helpfulPercent:
the "actions" presented in this game are pure nonsense.

Here are some of the things that you can do in this game that will apparently have consequences in your future:
1. Throw a football
2. Play darts

5. Put 3 pieces of paper in a binder

And the list goes on and on. These aren't real choices. This is rubbish. This is like claiming that if I have a chicken taco instead of a pizza

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I'd like to say that this seems like a really cool game so far. I love the environment, the style of graphics, and the mechanics (mostly lol). The story is quite intriguing and I like how the game progresses.

I'm not quite sure how to summarize the game for new players, which brings me to a few issues I've found so far.

When I first downloaded the game I made it through the first level pretty nicely. There were a few issues with mechanics, such as opening lower drawers while trying to close upper ones, and I was unable to activate the room across the hall from the starting bedroom. I had to quit playing in the middle of the opening cutscene of the second level as it was getting late.

When I tried to open the game again, I got a Steam notification saying that the executible was missing. I went through troubleshooting and was instructed to exit Steam, delete my appcache, restart my computer, then redownload the game.

After much trouble downloading the game again, I played through the first level once more. This time I still couldn't activate the same room and Emily did not activate after her second message. After putting all my stuff into the box, the box glitched through the floor and I lost the ability to pick anything else up, and therefore was forced to stop playing.

I know I focused on a lot of issues in this review, but this is a W.I.P. and overall I've really enjoyed the game so far.

I will give this game a reluctant thumbs up..

It's interesting, but certainly not the kind of game everyone will love, - or even like.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is a hard one to judge at this early stage. The story telling is pretty good and the interactivity is decent. The game is obviously still a work in progress as your progress can't be saved.

The story is pretty non existant at this early stage and uncovering it seems very confusing at times. I felt stuck after about 25 minutes with nothing left to explore or interact with.

Some of it is very rewarding though such as finding a flower in the garden, picking it and giving it to Emily. I can see a lot of potential for this game but I think the player needs abit more guidance while not hand holding, but a little nudge in the right directions.

You can check out my playthrough if you are still deciding to get it, there aren't major spoilers as it seems to be still very early game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=474154175

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has no save any where feature..No checkpoint system either. Continue does nothing. The game looks good.  I wish the person you first talk to had some more life to her. You talk to your girlfriend or boyfriend. Depends on what you pick when you start. I choose the girl. She looks good but doesnt have a lot of life to her. She stands in one place and moves her arms a little bit. She does talk but no lip sych and no voice.

Basically you move around and fix things inside the house by grabbing things. The colors really pop thanks to the black and white effect that goes away once you complete some thing.  In the game you can play horse shoes, dart and basketball. No scoring is kept however so its more to show off the engine then anything else. Interesting gameplay features so far.Once you tired of the house click on the car to move on to your office job.  Ok so far I have completed the main game. If this is so then is woeful super super super short. One hour of gameplay more or less. Once you get to your office you supposed to deliever packages to folks inside the office. Once you get tired of this mini game then you can leave your office and the game is over. It has some kind of scoring systems and thats the game. The graphics inside the office do not look very good at all. The people are all the same and sitting in chairs. However they are floating besides their chair and not sitting in the chair at all. I had one package I had to deliever with the description of Large written on it. Thats when I gave up and left the office and got the game over. Needs a lot of work to make it longer then one hour.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://youtu.be/HYdZ-bvuOJU

Reflections Review in 30Seconds

You’re going away to college and your future is still to be written. Well, in this case, painted. In this story telling adventure game, every time you interact with a person or object, it colorizes itself.

This is a genius life metaphor where Action and reaction become a visual effect that shows you how every interaction affects your destiny. Choices lead to different paths, and by the end you see how many life options you’ve unlocked.

That being said, there aren’t a lot of objects to interact with. But that’s life.

6 colors out of 10.

The graphics are a joy to look at. The open sandbox
recommended: and interact gameplay expand on the unique story. If I had to choose a personal favorite feature

reviewText:
Early Access Review

blessed be, everybody! it's me, woodlandfaerietruck, the patron saint of bundle games. what game have you given me today, jesus? oh wow this is really cool.  it's reflections, a 3d coloring book based off the movie pleasantville starring reese weatherspoon. we've got to give this one a try!

pretty much right away we see that there are some evil sinner devs involved in this one.  the game is in early access, so none of the characters from the movie are actually in the game yet.  i was really looking forward to coloring toby maguire like spiderman so i could reenact my favorite scenes from both spiderman and spiderman 2.  i can't believe the devs released this game before a single character was ready.  it seems very unprofessional, and makes me question if this game is indeed officially licensed from the movie studio.

as far as gameplay, from what i can tell, you just walk around and click on things to color them.  the single biggest sin committed by these evil sinner devs is spotted almost right away.  you can click to color things, but you don't get to pick what color you want them to be!  lord jesus, i pray that these sinner devs realize that you need at least a dozen or so color choices at minimum in order to make this game fun. even the worst sinner on earth deserves 2 or 3 choices.

another sin is the fact that the things to color are boring.  you want a coloring book based on the inside of your house?  that is all you get here.  my bible coloring book has all kinds of cool action scenes from the book of deuteronomy.  it doesn't even bother me that there are only 4 crayons left that i haven't eaten.  it is no fun to color a door or a desk or a toilet, especially if i can't choose the color.

the final sin came a bit later.  i got real depressed trying to get through coloring all the doors, and i needed a break to pray.  i came back, and the game had moved on by itself to the next scene in someone else's house.  did i win the first level? did i miss coloring too many things and lose?  i don't know. there was no message telling me if i won or lost or anything at all.

i am giving this game the old thumb from jesus's right hand pointed downward because no human sinner should have to suffer through it.  spend your time and money instead on a trip to the christian bookstore.  they have many wholesome coloring books to choose from. you will get much more enjoyment from those.

god bless amen

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a beautiful game. There are a few bugs and issues but It's in Early Access so that can be expected. The music and atmosphere are awesome and can completely relax you and let you enjoy the game with a better mind set than you may have had going into it for any reason (bad day at work, stressed, or haven't had your morning tacos yet).

Initially I thought the $10 price tag is a bit high because of the Early Access issues but after reading the most recent post from the writer/designer, I believe that what I wouldn't have wanted to pay for the game, would go directly to wanting to support the people working on it.

I got this game in a bundle and have more than gotten my monies worth. I am actually going to buy a copy or two for people because of how much I've enjoyed the game and how much I think others will like it too.
